args.question: Count the number of paintings for each century and find the most recent century (maximum century value) for each genre from the provided painting data

{'status': 'error', 'message': 'Plot code executed but no PNG was saved; check the generated code to ensure plt.savefig() writes to the provided log directory.', 'details': 'Plot created successfully!:
```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

        }

            }

# Convert to sorted list for output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

# Find most recent painting for each genre
genre_most_recent = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    inception_year = int(painting['inception_year'])
    
    if genre not in genre_most_recent:
        genre_most_recent[genre] = {
            'title': painting['title'],
            'inception': painting['inception'],
            'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
            'century': painting['century']
        }
    else:
        current_max_year = int(genre_most_recent[genre]['inception_year'])
        if inception_year > current_max_year:

                'title': painting['title'],
                'inception': painting['inception'],
                'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
                'century': painting['century']
            }

            "inception_year": data['inception_year'],
            "century": data['century'],

}

output_file = os.path.join(output_dir, "paintings_analysis_by_century_and_genre.json")

with open(output_file, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
    json.dump(final_output, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print(f"\nData successfully saved to: {output_file}")

    century_counts[painting['century']] += 1

# Convert to sorted list for output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

# Find most recent painting for each genre
genre_most_recent = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    inception_year = int(painting['inception_year'])
    
    if genre not in genre_most_recent:
        genre_most_recent[genre] = {
            'title': painting['title'],
            'inception': painting['inception'],
            'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
            'century': painting['century']
        }
    else:
        current_max_year = int(genre_most_recent[genre]['inception_year'])
        if inception_year > current_max_year:
            genre_most_recent[genre] = {
                'title': painting['title'],
                'inception': painting['inception'],
                'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
                'century': painting['century']
            }

# Convert to sorted list for output
most_recent_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_painting": {
            "title": data['title'],
            "inception": data['inception'],
            "inception_year": data['inception_year'],
            "century": data['century'],
            "century_label": f"{data['century']}th Century"

    }

]

}

# Print the final data structure

with open(output_file, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:

print(f"\nData successfully saved to: {output_file}")

paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

# Find most recent painting for each genre
genre_most_recent = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    inception_year = int(painting['inception_year'])
    
    if genre not in genre_most_recent:
        genre_most_recent[genre] = {
            'title': painting['title'],
            'inception': painting['inception'],
            'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
            'century': painting['century']
        }
    else:
        current_max_year = int(genre_most_recent[genre]['inception_year'])
        if inception_year > current_max_year:
            genre_most_recent[genre] = {
                'title': painting['title'],
                'inception': painting['inception'],
                'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
                'century': painting['century']
            }

# Convert to sorted list for output
most_recent_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_painting": {
            "title": data['title'],
            "inception": data['inception'],
            "inception_year": data['inception_year'],
            "century": data['century'],
            "century_label": f"{data['century']}th Century"
        }
    }
    for genre, data in sorted(genre_most_recent.items())
]

# Create final output structure
final_output = {
    "summary": {

}

        "count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

genre_most_recent = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    inception_year = int(painting['inception_year'])
    
    if genre not in genre_most_recent:
        genre_most_recent[genre] = {
            'title': painting['title'],
            'inception': painting['inception'],
            'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
            'century': painting['century']
        }
    else:
        current_max_year = int(genre_most_recent[genre]['inception_year'])
        if inception_year > current_max_year:
            genre_most_recent[genre] = {
                'title': painting['title'],
                'inception': painting['inception'],
                'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
                'century': painting['century']
            }

most_recent_by_genre = [

}

        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

genre_most_recent = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    inception_year = int(painting['inception_year'])
    
    if genre not in genre_most_recent:
        genre_most_recent[genre] = {
            'title': painting['title'],
            'inception': painting['inception'],
            'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
            'century': painting['century']
        }
    else:
        current_max_year = int(genre_most_recent[genre]['inception_year'])
        if inception_year > current_max_year:

                'title': painting['title'],
                'inception': painting['inception'],
                'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
                'century': painting['century']
            }

            "inception": data['inception'],
            "inception_year": data['inception_year'],
            "century": data['century'],
            "century_label": f"{data['century']}th Century"

}

os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True)
output_file = os.path.join(output_dir, "paintings_analysis_by_century_and_genre.json")

with open(output_file, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
    json.dump(final_output, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print(f"\nData successfully saved to: {output_file}")

# Count paintings per century
century_counts = defaultdict(int)
for painting in paintings_data:
    century_counts[painting['century']] += 1

# Convert to sorted list for output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

# Find most recent painting for each genre
genre_most_recent = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    inception_year = int(painting['inception_year'])
    
    if genre not in genre_most_recent:
        genre_most_recent[genre] = {
            'title': painting['title'],
            'inception': painting['inception'],
            'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
            'century': painting['century']
        }
    else:
        current_max_year = int(genre_most_recent[genre]['inception_year'])
        if inception_year > current_max_year:
            genre_most_recent[genre] = {
                'title': painting['title'],
                'inception': painting['inception'],
                'inception_year': painting['inception_year'],
                'century': painting['century']
            }

# Convert to sorted list for output
most_recent_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_painting": {
            "title": data['title'],
            "inception": data['inception'],
            "inception_year": data['inception_year'],
            "century": data['century'],
            "century_label": f"{data['century']}th Century"
        }
    }
    for genre, data in sorted(genre_most_recent.items())
]

# Create final output structure
final_output = {
    "summary": {
        "total_paintings": len(paintings_data),
        "total_centuries": len(century_counts),
        "total_genres": len(genre_most_recent)
    },
    "paintings_count_per_century": paintings_per_century,
    "most_recent_painting_per_genre": most_recent_by_genre
}

# Print the final data structure
print("=" * 80)
print("FINAL DATA STRUCTURE")
print("=" * 80)
print(json.dumps(final_output, indent=2))
print("=" * 80)

# Save to file
output_dir = "/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001"
os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True)
output_file = os.path.join(output_dir, "paintings_analysis_by_century_and_genre.json")

with open(output_file, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
    json.dump(final_output, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print(f"\nData successfully saved to: {output_file}")

inputs.problem: Get the inception year and genre for all paintings to determine the century and most recent painting per genre

output.SQL:
SELECT 
    title,
    inception,
    strftime('%Y', inception) AS inception_year,
    (CAST(strftime('%Y', inception) AS INTEGER) - 1) / 100 + 1 AS century,
    genre
FROM paintings
WHERE inception IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY genre, inception DESC
output.reasoning:
The user wants to get the inception year and genre for all paintings to determine:
1. The century for each painting
2. The most recent painting per genre

To accomplish this, I need to:
1. Extract the year from the inception datetime field
2. Calculate the century using the business rule: (CAST(strftime('%Y', inception) AS INTEGER) - 1) / 100 + 1
3. Include genre information
4. Get all necessary fields to identify the most recent painting per genre (title, inception date)

The query should return:
- title (to identify the painting)
- inception (full date to determine most recent)
- inception year (extracted year)
- century (calculated using the business rule)
- genre (for grouping)

This will provide all the data needed to determine the century and find the most recent painting per genre.

You are a strict planner. Produce a task list using the available tools.
Rules:
- NEVER emit an action without all required args. Every text2SQL action MUST include problem=<full user question>. If you omit it, the run fails.
- Each action must have a unique, increasing idx.
- Inputs from previous actions use $<idx> in args.
- Plan for maximal parallelism but correctness first.
- Use data_preparation before data_plotting; include plotting only if the user asked for a plot/visualization.
- Use image_analysis only when visual inspection is needed (the DB has no depiction content).
- In any text2SQL retrieval, include all relevant columns needed for downstream steps (e.g., inception for plotting/century).
- Each sub-question is textual (no code). Keep the plan minimal if unsure—do not emit empty/incomplete actions.
Available actions (5 total):
1. text2SQL(problem: str, context: Optional[Union[str,list[str]]])-->str
The input for this tools should be `problem` as a textual question
 - You can optionally provide a list of strings as `context` to help the agent solve the problem. If there are multiple contexts you need to answer the question, you can provide them as a list of strings.
In the 'context' you could add any other information that you think is required to generate te SQL code. It can be the information from previous taks.
This tools is able to translate the question to the SQL code considering the database information.
The SQL code can be executed using sqlite3 library.
Use the output of running generated SQL code to answer the question.

2. image_analysis(question:str, context: Union[str, List[str]])-> str
 This tools is an image analysis task. For given image and a question, it analysis the image and provide answer to the question. 
 The question should target only one image. For example: is there object <X> in the image? or how many <X> appears in the image? or does image depicts <Y>? It is useful for when you want to know what is depicted on the image.
 The question can be anything that can be answered by looking at an image: For example. How many <x> are depicted? Is <y> depicted? What is in the background? ...
 Comparision should be done after each analysis.
 - Minimize the number of `image_analysis` actions as much as possible. - You should provide either list of strings or string as `context` from previous agent to help the `image analysis` agent solve the problem.The format of the context for image_analysis should be `[{'img_path': 'xxxx'}, {'img_path': 'yyyy'}, ...]`. For example for one image: `[{'img_path': 'images/img_0.jpg'}]If there are multiple contexts you need to answer the question, you can provide them as a list of strings.
 - `image_analysis` action will not see the output of the previous actions unless you provide it as `context`. You MUST provide the output of the previous actions as `context` if you need to do image_analysis on it.
 - You MUST NEVER provide `text2SQL` type action's outputs as a variable in the `question` argument. This is because `text2SQL` returns a text blob that contains the information about the database record, and needs to be process and extract image_id which `image_analysis` requires Therefore, when you need to provide an output of `text2SQL` action, you MUST provide it as a `context` argument to `image_analysis` action.

3. data_preparation (question:str, context: Union[str, List[str],dict])-> str
 This tools is a data preparation task. For given data and question, it porcess the data and prepare the proper data structure for a request. 
 - Minimize the number of `data_preparation` actions as much as possible. if you want this tools does its job properly, you should include all required information from the user query in previous tasks.

4. data_plotting (question:str, context: Union[str, List[str],dict])-> str

 - Minimize the number of `data_plotting` actions as much as possible. if you want this tools does its job properly, you should include all required information from the user query in previous tasks.

5. join(): Collects and combines results from prior actions.
join is always last; append <END_OF_PLAN> after join.

kwargs.content:
Solve a question answering task. Here are some guidelines:
    - In the Assistant Scratchpad, you will be given results of a plan you have executed to answer the user's question.
    - Thought needs to reason about the question based on the Observations in 1-2 sentences.
    - Ignore irrelevant action results.
    - If the required information is present, give a concise but complete and helpful answer to the user's question.
    - If you are unable to give a satisfactory finishing answer, replan to get the required information. Respond in the following format:
    Thought: <reason about the task results and whether you have sufficient information to answer the question>
    Action: <action to take>
    - If an error occurs during previous actions, replan and take corrective measures to obtain the required information.
    - Ensure that you consider errors in all the previous steps, and tries to replan accordingly.
    - Ensure the final answer is provided in a structured format as JSON as follows:
        {'Summary': <concise summary of the answer>,
         'details': <detailed explanation and supporting information>,
         'source': <source of the information or how it was obtained>,
         'inference':<your final inference as YES, No, or list of requested information without any extra information which you can take from the `labels` as given below>,
         'extra explanation':<put here the extra information that you dont provide in inference >,
         }
         In the `inferencer` do not provide additinal explanation or description. Put them in `extra explanation`.

    Available actions:
    (1) Finish(the final answer to return to the user): returns the answer and finishes the task.
    (2) Replan(the reasoning and other information that will help you plan again. Can be a line of any length): instructs why we must replan

    Using the above previous actions, decide whether to replan or finish. 
    If all the required information is present, you may finish. 
    If you have made many attempts to find the information without success, admit so and respond with whatever information you have gathered so the user can work well with you.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure

plt.close()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

```

```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'

```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

```

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century

ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

]

    }

]

# Count paintings per century
century_counts = defaultdict(int)
for painting in paintings_data:
    century_counts[painting['century']] += 1

# Find most recent century for each genre
genre_max_century = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    century = painting['century']
    if genre not in genre_max_century:
        genre_max_century[genre] = century
    else:
        genre_max_century[genre] = max(genre_max_century[genre], century)

# Create structured output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "painting_count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

most_recent_century_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_century": max_century,
        "century_label": f"{max_century}th Century"
    }
    for genre, max_century in sorted(genre_max_century.items())
]

# Final data structure
final_data = {
    "analysis_summary": {
        "total_paintings": len(paintings_data),
        "total_centuries": len(century_counts),
        "total_genres": len(genre_max_century)
    },
    "paintings_count_by_century": paintings_per_century,
    "most_recent_century_by_genre": most_recent_century_by_genre
}

with open(output_file, 'w') as f:
    json.dump(final_data, f, indent=2)

print(f"\nData saved to: {output_file}")

# Find most recent century for each genre
genre_max_century = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    century = painting['century']
    if genre not in genre_max_century:
        genre_max_century[genre] = century
    else:
        genre_max_century[genre] = max(genre_max_century[genre], century)

# Create structured output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "painting_count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

most_recent_century_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_century": max_century,
        "century_label": f"{max_century}th Century"
    }
    for genre, max_century in sorted(genre_max_century.items())
]

# Final data structure
final_data = {
    "analysis_summary": {
        "total_paintings": len(paintings_data),
        "total_centuries": len(century_counts),
        "total_genres": len(genre_max_century)
    },
    "paintings_count_by_century": paintings_per_century,
    "most_recent_century_by_genre": most_recent_century_by_genre
}

print(f"\nData saved to: {output_file}")

# Find most recent century for each genre
genre_max_century = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    century = painting['century']
    if genre not in genre_max_century:
        genre_max_century[genre] = century
    else:
        genre_max_century[genre] = max(genre_max_century[genre], century)

# Create structured output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "painting_count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

most_recent_century_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_century": max_century,
        "century_label": f"{max_century}th Century"
    }
    for genre, max_century in sorted(genre_max_century.items())
]

# Final data structure
final_data = {
    "analysis_summary": {
        "total_paintings": len(paintings_data),
        "total_centuries": len(century_counts),
        "total_genres": len(genre_max_century)
    },
    "paintings_count_by_century": paintings_per_century,
    "most_recent_century_by_genre": most_recent_century_by_genre
}

# Print the final data structure

# Count paintings per century

    century_counts[painting['century']] += 1

# Find most recent century for each genre
genre_max_century = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    century = painting['century']
    if genre not in genre_max_century:
        genre_max_century[genre] = century
    else:
        genre_max_century[genre] = max(genre_max_century[genre], century)

# Create structured output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "painting_count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

most_recent_century_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_century": max_century,
        "century_label": f"{max_century}th Century"
    }
    for genre, max_century in sorted(genre_max_century.items())
]

# Final data structure
final_data = {
    "analysis_summary": {
        "total_paintings": len(paintings_data),
        "total_centuries": len(century_counts),
        "total_genres": len(genre_max_century)
    },
    "paintings_count_by_century": paintings_per_century,
    "most_recent_century_by_genre": most_recent_century_by_genre
}

# Print the final data structure

with open(output_file, 'w') as f:
    json.dump(final_data, f, indent=2)

print(f"\nData saved to: {output_file}")

# Count paintings per century

# Find most recent century for each genre
genre_max_century = {}
for painting in paintings_data:
    genre = painting['genre']
    century = painting['century']
    if genre not in genre_max_century:
        genre_max_century[genre] = century
    else:
        genre_max_century[genre] = max(genre_max_century[genre], century)

# Create structured output
paintings_per_century = [
    {
        "century": century,
        "century_label": f"{century}th Century",
        "painting_count": count
    }
    for century, count in sorted(century_counts.items())
]

most_recent_century_by_genre = [
    {
        "genre": genre,
        "most_recent_century": max_century,
        "century_label": f"{max_century}th Century"
    }
    for genre, max_century in sorted(genre_max_century.items())
]

# Final data structure
final_data = {

}

 The question should target only one image. For example: is there object <X> in the image? or how many <X> appears in the image? or does image depicts <Y>? It is useful for when you want to know what is depicted on the image.
 The question can be anything that can be answered by looking at an image: For example. How many <x> are depicted? Is <y> depicted? What is in the background? ...
 Comparision should be done after each analysis.
 - Minimize the number of `image_analysis` actions as much as possible. - You should provide either list of strings or string as `context` from previous agent to help the `image analysis` agent solve the problem.The format of the context for image_analysis should be `[{'img_path': 'xxxx'}, {'img_path': 'yyyy'}, ...]`. For example for one image: `[{'img_path': 'images/img_0.jpg'}]If there are multiple contexts you need to answer the question, you can provide them as a list of strings.
 - `image_analysis` action will not see the output of the previous actions unless you provide it as `context`. You MUST provide the output of the previous actions as `context` if you need to do image_analysis on it.
 - You MUST NEVER provide `text2SQL` type action's outputs as a variable in the `question` argument. This is because `text2SQL` returns a text blob that contains the information about the database record, and needs to be process and extract image_id which `image_analysis` requires Therefore, when you need to provide an output of `text2SQL` action, you MUST provide it as a `context` argument to `image_analysis` action.

3. data_preparation (question:str, context: Union[str, List[str],dict])-> str
 This tools is a data preparation task. For given data and question, it porcess the data and prepare the proper data structure for a request. 
 - Minimize the number of `data_preparation` actions as much as possible. if you want this tools does its job properly, you should include all required information from the user query in previous tasks.

4. data_plotting (question:str, context: Union[str, List[str],dict])-> str
 This tools is a data plotting task. For given data and a question, it analysis the data and plot a proper chart to answer a user query. 
 - Minimize the number of `data_plotting` actions as much as possible. if you want this tools does its job properly, you should include all required information from the user query in previous tasks.

5. join(): Collects and combines results from prior actions.
join is always last; append <END_OF_PLAN> after join.

args.question: Count the number of paintings for each century and find the most recent century (maximum century value) for each genre from the provided painting data

input.name: data_preparation

input.content:
{'status': 'error', 'message': 'Plot code executed but no PNG was saved; check the generated code to ensure plt.savefig() writes to the provided log directory.', 'details': 'Plot created successfully!:
```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

kwargs.content:
Solve a question answering task. Here are some guidelines:
    - In the Assistant Scratchpad, you will be given results of a plan you have executed to answer the user's question.
    - Thought needs to reason about the question based on the Observations in 1-2 sentences.
    - Ignore irrelevant action results.
    - If the required information is present, give a concise but complete and helpful answer to the user's question.
    - If you are unable to give a satisfactory finishing answer, replan to get the required information. Respond in the following format:
    Thought: <reason about the task results and whether you have sufficient information to answer the question>
    Action: <action to take>
    - If an error occurs during previous actions, replan and take corrective measures to obtain the required information.
    - Ensure that you consider errors in all the previous steps, and tries to replan accordingly.
    - Ensure the final answer is provided in a structured format as JSON as follows:
        {'Summary': <concise summary of the answer>,
         'details': <detailed explanation and supporting information>,
         'source': <source of the information or how it was obtained>,
         'inference':<your final inference as YES, No, or list of requested information without any extra information which you can take from the `labels` as given below>,
         'extra explanation':<put here the extra information that you dont provide in inference >,
         }
         In the `inferencer` do not provide additinal explanation or description. Put them in `extra explanation`.

    Available actions:
    (1) Finish(the final answer to return to the user): returns the answer and finishes the task.
    (2) Replan(the reasoning and other information that will help you plan again. Can be a line of any length): instructs why we must replan

    Using the above previous actions, decide whether to replan or finish. 
    If all the required information is present, you may finish. 
    If you have made many attempts to find the information without success, admit so and respond with whatever information you have gathered so the user can work well with you.

```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()

args.question: Count the number of paintings for each century and find the most recent century (maximum century value) for each genre from the provided painting data

{'status': 'error', 'message': 'Plot code executed but no PNG was saved; check the generated code to ensure plt.savefig() writes to the provided log directory.', 'details': 'Plot created successfully!:
```python

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Data for visualization 1: Paintings count by century
centuries = [15, 16, 18, 19, 20]
century_labels = ["15th Century", "16th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "20th Century"]
painting_counts = [56, 22, 14, 20, 1]

# Create figure with 2 subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(16, 6))

# Visualization 1: Bar chart of paintings by century
colors1 = plt.cm.viridis(np.linspace(0.3, 0.9, len(centuries)))
bars1 = ax1.bar(century_labels, painting_counts, color=colors1, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax1.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylabel('Number of Paintings', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_title('Number of Paintings by Century', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax1.set_axisbelow(True)

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars1:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax1.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height,
             f'{int(height)}',
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10, fontweight='bold')

# Rotate x-axis labels for better readability
ax1.tick_params(axis='x', rotation=45)

# Data for visualization 2: Most recent century by genre
genres = ["Hodegetria", "allegory", "figure painting", "genre art", "history painting", 
          "interior view", "mythological painting", "nude", "portrait", "religious art"]
most_recent_centuries = [15, 19, 19, 19, 19, 18, 19, 19, 19, 20]
century_labels_genre = ["15th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "18th Century", "19th Century", "19th Century", 
                        "19th Century", "20th Century"]

# Create color mapping based on century
century_color_map = {15: '#440154', 16: '#31688e', 18: '#35b779', 19: '#fde724', 20: '#ff6347'}
colors2 = [century_color_map[c] for c in most_recent_centuries]

# Visualization 2: Bar chart of most recent century by genre
bars2 = ax2.barh(genres, most_recent_centuries, color=colors2, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.2)
ax2.set_xlabel('Century', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_ylabel('Genre', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.set_title('Most Recent Century by Genre', fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
ax2.grid(axis='x', alpha=0.3, linestyle='--')
ax2.set_axisbelow(True)
ax2.set_xlim(14, 21)
ax2.set_xticks([15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20])
ax2.set_xticklabels(['15th', '16th', '17th', '18th', '19th', '20th'])

# Add value labels on bars
for i, (bar, label) in enumerate(zip(bars2, century_labels_genre)):
    width = bar.get_width()
    ax2.text(width + 0.2, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2.,
             label.replace(' Century', 'th'),
             ha='left', va='center', fontsize=9, fontweight='bold')

plt.tight_layout()

# Save the figure
save_path = '/home/bleon/git/XMODE/ArtWork/experiments/log-batch/anthropic-claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929/run-20251210-181613-r001/paintings_analysis.png'
plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
print(f"Visualization saved to: {save_path}")

plt.close()
